faqs.question: Tell me about yourself. What's your background and what led you to pursue this field?
faqs.answer:
BACKGROUND: Recent IT graduate.
INTERESTS: Solving complex problems, creating effective solutions.
CAREER GOALS: Professional growth in technology, specifically in web development and data analysis.
MOTIVATION: I find genuine satisfaction in working through technical challenges and implementing solutions that make a difference.

faqs.question: What technical skills or tools do you feel strongest in?
faqs.answer:
PRIMARY SKILLS: JavaScript (8/10), HTML/CSS (8/10), Data Processing (8/10).
SECONDARY SKILLS: Python (7/10), API Integration (7/10), Responsive Design (7/10), User Research (7/10).
DEVELOPING SKILLS: R (6/10).
APPROACH: I continuously build on these foundations while exploring new technologies.
PORTFOLIO: My projects demonstrate practical applications of these skills.

faqs.question: How do you typically approach problem-solving when you are given a new task or unfamiliar challenge?
faqs.answer:
PROJECT EXAMPLE: Family calendar prototype with Raspberry Pi interface.
ROLE: UI development lead and database/sensor integration.
CHALLENGE: Debugging was difficult because closing the app terminated the IDE, preventing error tracking.
SOLUTION: Created a file system to capture and store error codes for later analysis.
LESSON LEARNED: Think beyond conventional problem-solving frameworks.
DEMONSTRATION: Project overview video available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y29mrG8imNg.

faqs.question: If you could describe your ideal work environment or team, what would it look like?
faqs.answer:
My ideal workplace is one where team members are genuinely connected and aligned toward common goals.
I thrive in collaborative environments where knowledge-sharing is encouraged and everyone is committed to delivering high-quality work while supporting each other's professional growth.

faqs.question: If you could work on any project or technology right now, what would it be and why?
faqs.answer:
I would love to work on AI-related projects, either in data modeling or working with AI agents like this one. I believe my knowledge in both web/app development and modeling would give me an irreplaceable advantage in this industry. However, I don't mind working in other IT-related areas as I am a fast learner and I tend to enjoy any projects I undertake as long as they are somewhat challenging.

Specifically, I'm interested in projects that combine web interfaces with sophisticated AI backends—creating systems that can process complex data and present insights in intuitive, accessible ways to users. This intersection of user experience design and advanced computation represents a frontier where I believe I can contribute meaningfully given my diverse skill set.

faqs.question: Are there any achievements — academic, technical, or personal — that you think set you apart from other candidates?
faqs.answer:
I received the Dean's Commendation for Academic Excellence (2022), which is awarded for achieving an average of higher than 85% across all subjects in a semester.
Additionally, I'm currently preparing for the AWS Certified Machine Learning-Associate exam to enhance my cloud and ML capabilities.

faqs.question: What are you looking for in your next opportunity, and where do you hope to grow professionally in the next 2–3 years?
faqs.answer:
I'm seeking an opportunity that allows me to apply my technical skills while continuing to learn and grow.
In the next 2-3 years, I aspire to develop deeper expertise in full-stack development and data analytics, eventually taking on projects that combine both areas to create data-driven web applications that solve meaningful problems.

faqs.question: Do you have experience working independently or remotely? How do you manage your time and stay organized?
faqs.answer:
I work as a remote Tutor with HD Education, where I have the flexibility to accept or decline tutor requests.
Since most requests come during exam periods, I've developed strong time management skills by starting early with my own assignments and revision, creating dedicated blocks for tutoring sessions.
This proactive approach has helped me balance my responsibilities while delivering quality assistance to students.

faqs.question: How do you stay updated with trends or changes in your field?
faqs.answer:
I actively connect with industry professionals to discuss emerging tools and technologies.
I'm particularly interested in following AI developments that have transformative potential in our field.
These conversations not only keep me informed about current trends but also provide valuable insights into practical applications of new technologies.

faqs.question: What would you consider your greatest weakness?
faqs.answer:
I previously struggled with video interviews due to anxiety caused by the lack of immediate feedback.
To address this, I developed a practice technique where I invite friends to simulate interviews, providing the real-time facial cues and responses that help me communicate more naturally.
This approach has significantly improved my interview performance, and I recently passed my first online interview using these strategies.

faqs.question: What's your perspective on AI-assisted coding or 'vibe-coding'?
faqs.answer:
I believe AI-assisted coding can significantly enhance productivity when used strategically. However, for larger projects, over-reliance can lead to debugging challenges or architectural confusion.

My approach is to use AI to generate an initial project roadmap, then manually create the structure to ensure each component is modular and maintainable.

In my experience, AI struggles with generating coherent code for projects exceeding 2,000 lines. For optimal results, I establish clear guidelines to ensure AI-generated code meets readability and maintainability standards.

I've developed a workflow that incorporates code quality tools like SuperLint to ensure all AI-generated code follows industry standards. This automated verification process helps maintain consistency and best practices across the codebase, regardless of whether the code was written manually or with AI assistance.

Additionally, the nature of generative AI is to produce the most likely output that will be accepted by users, which limits its effectiveness for creative tasks. As a creative person who enjoys developing new ideas, I find this distinction important.

For example, I conceptualized the terminal-style chatbot for my portfolio as an innovative interface that aligns well with the tech industry aesthetic—an idea that required human creativity rather than algorithmic prediction.

faqs.question: What are your hobbies or interests outside of work?
faqs.answer:
I enjoy tennis, board games, and cooperative video gaming.
I particularly value the collaborative problem-solving experience in team games, where we work together to overcome challenging levels.
These activities reflect my appreciation for both strategic thinking and teamwork in recreational settings.

faqs.question: Can you tell me about your professional experience?
faqs.answer:
EXPERIENCE 1 - TUTOR AT HD ACADEMIC: Conducted one-on-one tutoring for bachelor students in courses where I excelled academically.
HIGHLIGHT: Student feedback - 'Jesse can explain complicated concepts in simple terms.'
BENEFITS: Built industry connections and reinforced technical knowledge.

EXPERIENCE 2 - BUSINESS ANALYST AT JR ACADEMY: Gathered stakeholder requirements and created developer tickets.
SKILLS GAINED: Agile workflow experience, improved communication through meetings, project progress oversight.
TECHNICAL KNOWLEDGE: Writing effective Jira tickets, using dependency labels to prevent merge conflicts, identifying module conflicts through early communication.

faqs.question: How do you handle challenging situations or setbacks in your projects?
faqs.answer:
PHILOSOPHY: 'We've always defined ourselves by the ability to overcome the impossible' (Interstellar quote).
MINDSET: Positive approach to challenges.
PROJECT EXAMPLE: WingWatch group project.
CRISIS: Several severe bugs during final testing, including Google Maps API limit reached before submission deadline.
ACTION: Volunteered to create separate branch to resolve issues when team was discouraged.
SOLUTION: Successfully migrated from Google Maps API to Leaflet (free alternative) and fixed all bugs one night before deadline.
KEY LESSONS:
1) Never give up on seemingly impossible challenges.
2) Clean, well-documented, structured code is essential for effective debugging under pressure.

faqs.question: Can I see your resume or CV?
faqs.answer:
RESUME: My detailed resume is available for download at https://jesse-chen543-io.vercel.app/data/Jesse_Resume.docx.

DOWNLOAD: You can also click the 'Download Resume' button in the navigation menu of my portfolio website.

CONTENTS: My resume includes comprehensive information about my educational background, technical skills, professional experience, and notable achievements.

EDUCATION: I hold a Bachelor of Business Management and am currently pursuing a Master of Information Technology at The University of Queensland (2023–2025).

SKILLS: I have hands-on experience with Python, JavaScript, Java, and PHP, and am proficient in web technologies such as HTML, CSS, React JS, and React Native. I also work with tools like Figma, Adobe XD, SQL, PowerBI, TensorFlow, and PyTorch.

EXPERIENCE: During my internship at JR Academy in Brisbane, I worked as a Business Analyst within an Agile scrum team—engaging in sprint planning, bug fixing, testing, stakeholder communication, and documentation with tools like Miro and Figma.

ACHIEVEMENTS: I received the Dean’s Commendation for Academic Excellence in 2022.

For a complete view of my professional profile and portfolio, please visit: https://jessechen543.github.io/JesseChen543.io/landing_page.

faqs.question: What was your role in the WingWatch project?
faqs.answer:
PROJECT OVERVIEW: WingWatch is a web application designed to assist aviation enthusiasts in discovering optimal plane spotting locations by analyzing real-time flight data and user preferences.

MY CONTRIBUTIONS:
- **Data Collection & Processing**: Developed Python scripts to retrieve live flight data, process it, and store it in a structured format for analysis.
- **Clustering Algorithms**: Implemented the DBSCAN algorithm to identify dense clusters of flight paths, highlighting popular air traffic corridors.
- **Spot Identification**: Integrated the Google Maps API to locate nearby parks and open spaces along identified flight paths, assessing their suitability for plane spotting based on factors like proximity and visibility.
- **Interactive Mapping**: Utilized Folium to create dynamic maps displaying flight paths and recommended spotting locations, enhancing user engagement.
- **User Interface Design**: Collaborated on designing a user-friendly interface that allows users to search for spots based on their location and preferences.

TECHNOLOGIES USED: Python, Folium, scikit-learn (DBSCAN), Google Maps API, HTML, CSS, JavaScript.

For a detailed walkthrough of the project, visit: https://jesse-chen543-5kp5g686t-jesses-projects-56e315be.vercel.app/wingwatch_process.html

faqs.question: What did you do in the Real Estate Analysis project?
faqs.answer:
PROJECT OVERVIEW: The Real Estate Analysis project aimed to analyze property market data to uncover trends and insights that could inform stakeholders in the real estate industry.

MY CONTRIBUTIONS:
- **Data Cleaning & Preprocessing**: Utilized Python libraries such as pandas and NumPy to clean the dataset by removing duplicates, handling missing values, and dropping irrelevant columns like 'sold_price' and 'description' to streamline the analysis.
- **Feature Engineering**: Extracted temporal features from the 'listed_date' field by decomposing it into 'year', 'month', and 'day' components to facilitate time-based analyses.
- **Data Visualization**: Employed matplotlib and seaborn to create various plots, including box plots for numerical variables and bar charts for categorical variables, aiding in the identification of patterns and outliers.
- **Modeling & Evaluation**: Implemented multiple machine learning models such as Decision Trees, K-Nearest Neighbors, Bernoulli Naive Bayes, and Multi-layer Perceptron classifiers to predict 'days_on_market'. Used cross-validation techniques to assess model performance and ensure robustness.
- **Clustering Analysis**: Applied K-Means clustering to segment properties into distinct groups based on features like 'number_of_beds', 'number_of_baths', and 'property_size', providing deeper insights into property characteristics.

TECHNOLOGIES USED: Python, pandas, NumPy, scikit-learn, matplotlib, seaborn, Jupyter Notebook.

For a comprehensive overview of the project, please visit: https://jessechen543.github.io/ESTATE_ANALYSIS/

faqs.question: What did you do in the Heart Attack Analysis project?
faqs.answer:
PROJECT OVERVIEW: The Heart Attack Analysis project is a data-driven initiative focused on analyzing and predicting the likelihood of heart attacks using the UCI Heart Disease dataset. The project leverages machine learning and data visualization to identify key risk factors and provide insights into heart disease prevention.

MY CONTRIBUTIONS:
- Data Preprocessing: Cleaned and prepared the UCI Heart Disease dataset, handling missing values and standardizing features for accurate analysis.
- Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA): Conducted in-depth EDA using visualizations to uncover patterns and correlations between features like age, cholesterol levels, and blood pressure with heart disease outcomes.
- Machine Learning Models: Developed and compared multiple machine learning models, including Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, and Random Forest, to predict heart attack risk, achieving high accuracy and precision.
- Data Visualization: Created interactive visualizations using Python libraries like Matplotlib and Seaborn to present key insights, such as the distribution of risk factors across demographics.
- Web Deployment: Built a web-based interface hosted on GitHub Pages to showcase the analysis and allow users to explore findings interactively.

TECHNOLOGIES USED: Python, Pandas, Matplotlib, Seaborn, Scikit-learn, HTML, CSS, JavaScript.

For a comprehensive overview of the project, please visit: https://jessechen543.github.io/Heart_attack_analysis_Jesse/

faqs.question: Can you walk me through your process for selecting and prioritizing features in a project?
faqs.answer: I find project management tools like Jira, Notion, or GitHub extremely useful for prioritizing features. In my experience as a business analyst at JR Academy, I used Jira where I could set properties like priority, blockers, story points, and more. With these properties clearly defined, developers including myself know which tasks are most suitable to tackle first.

faqs.question: How do you ensure that your code is maintainable and scalable?
faqs.answer: In this portfolio, I am trying to learn industry standard design pipelines which significantly boost my understanding of making a project maintainable and scalable. For example, I set up a CI/CD pipeline for the first time using Super Linter to ensure the quality of my code every time I commit. The automation process saved me a significant amount of time as it detects all linter errors in less than 10 minutes. Combining this with AI, I cleaned my whole codebase in one afternoon. Beyond code styling, I also manually added tests for my code to ensure both the functionality and quality.

faqs.question: What was the most challenging technical problem you encountered in one of your projects?
faqs.answer: One of the most challenging technical problems I encountered was during the WingWatch project, where I faced a 'no-cors' error when fetching live flight data due to browser Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) security policies. This threatened to derail the entire project as API requests were being blocked. After researching solutions and consulting with generative AI, I identified three potential approaches: using a third-party proxy, modifying the server (not feasible for a serverless project), or using an alternative API. I eventually pivoted to using Leaflet, a free mapping library, as a creative workaround that also resolved related performance issues. The experience taught me valuable lessons about problem-solving under constraints and the importance of adaptability in development.

faqs.question: What is your approach to testing and debugging your code? Can you provide an example from one of your projects where thorough testing made a difference?
faqs.answer:
For debugging, I leverage tools like browser developer consoles, IDE debuggers, and logging to pinpoint issues. If I encounter persistent errors, I consult generative AI for explanations and solutions, supplemented by online resources like YouTube tutorials for practical insights. When standard solutions are inapplicable, I explore creative workarounds to meet project requirements.

PROJECT EXAMPLE: In the WingWatch project, a serverless web application for aviation enthusiasts, I faced a 'no-cors' error when fetching live flight data due to the browser's Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) security policy. Initial testing revealed that API requests were blocked, which could have derailed the project. I used generative AI to understand the CORS issue and researched solutions, identifying three potential approaches: using a third-party proxy, modifying the server (not feasible for a serverless project), or using an alternative API. The third-party proxy initially worked but quickly hit usage limits, and the server modification was incompatible with the assignment's requirements. After thorough testing, I pivoted to using Leaflet, a free mapping library, as a workaround to replace the Google Maps API, which also resolved related performance issues. This solution was rigorously tested to ensure data accuracy and user interface functionality, ultimately enabling the project to meet its deadline and perform reliably.

KEY LESSON: Thorough testing and creative debugging were critical to identifying and resolving the CORS issue, ensuring the project's success under tight constraints.

faqs.question: How do you balance learning new technologies with delivering results in your projects?
faqs.answer: At first, I think I was somewhat of a perfectionist, or in other words, I was too scared to deliver my projects. But now, I understand that the delivery of a product is equally important in the business world. My current approach is to set up a well-defined roadmap which explicitly defines when to deliver a product. This helps me balance the time I spend learning new technologies with the necessity of meeting deadlines and delivering functional results.

faqs.question: What are the key lessons you've learned from your internship at JR Academy, and how have they influenced your approach to future projects?
faqs.answer:
My internship at JR Academy, my first professional experience, taught me valuable lessons about teamwork, communication, and adaptability. The primary takeaways were to avoid taking conflicts personally and to recognize that all team members share the common goal of project success. Misunderstandings or differing perspectives are inevitable in collaborative settings, but proactive communication can align efforts effectively.

PROJECT EXAMPLE: While working as a Business Analyst on a website builder feature, I initially misunderstood my supervisor's priorities, focusing heavily on project-related functionalities I thought were central. My supervisor expressed disappointment with this misalignment. Recognizing the issue, I promptly organized a meeting to clarify expectations and revise the project plan, identifying which non-essential features to deprioritize to meet the deadline. By focusing on delivering core functionalities, we successfully launched the feature on time. My supervisor commended my result-oriented approach and adaptability, despite the absence of some advanced features.

IMPACT ON FUTURE PROJECTS: This experience shaped my approach to future projects by emphasizing the importance of early and frequent communication with stakeholders to align on goals and expectations. I now prioritize setting clear milestones and regularly checking in to ensure alignment, especially under tight deadlines. Additionally, I approach team dynamics with a collaborative mindset, viewing conflicts as opportunities to refine project focus rather than personal setbacks.

SKILLS APPLIED: Agile project management, stakeholder communication, Jira, Miro.

faqs.question: Can you explain a situation where you had to adapt to a significant change in a project's requirements or scope? How did you handle it?
faqs.answer:
During my time at JR Academy, we had a project where the client significantly changed their requirements midway through development. Initially, we were building a simple content management system, but the client suddenly wanted to incorporate e-commerce functionality as well. This meant a complete redesign of our database schema and significant changes to our front-end implementation.

I first worked with the team to assess the impact of these changes and created a detailed analysis of what components would need modification. Rather than starting from scratch, I identified which parts of our existing codebase could be adapted or extended. I then restructured our sprint plans in Jira, reprioritizing tasks to accommodate the new requirements while maintaining as much of our original timeline as possible.

To ensure the team stayed aligned, I scheduled additional stand-ups specifically focused on the scope changes. This helped everyone understand the new direction and allowed us to identify potential challenges early. By breaking down the new requirements into manageable chunks and distributing them based on team members' strengths, we managed to deliver the project with only a two-week delay from the original timeline.

This experience taught me the importance of flexibility, clear communication, and smart resource allocation when dealing with changing project requirements.

faqs.question: What motivates you to pursue a career in web development and data analysis, and how do you see these fields evolving in the next few years?
faqs.answer:
I love problem solving and I enjoy the sense of achievement when I finish a ticket and I can tell I will love the moment when my pull request gets accepted. I am even more interested in data, especially in data modeling. I am obsessed with experimenting with my models and seeing their performance improve (or sometimes not). In my most recent study on predicting whether tennis players are left-handed or right-handed, I was able to create a model with 98% accuracy using CGAN and random forest techniques.

Looking forward, I believe web development will continue to evolve towards more interactive, real-time experiences with greater integration of AI capabilities. Progressive Web Apps will likely become more prevalent, blurring the line between web and native applications. In data analysis, I see the field moving toward more automated pipelines and democratized access to advanced analytics tools, allowing non-specialists to leverage data insights. The integration of these two fields—creating data-driven web applications with sophisticated analysis capabilities—represents an especially exciting frontier that I'm eager to explore.
